conclusion: Problem involves a conveyor belt moving at a certain speed with an object placed on it to find work done by friction.
Conveyor belt speed is 6 m/s, distance between wheels M and N is 10 m, object mass is 3 kg, coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.3.
Object is placed gently on the conveyor belt, starting from rest relative to the ground.
Kinetic friction will cause the object to accelerate until it reaches the speed of the conveyor belt.
Determine if the object reaches conveyor belt speed before reaching point N by calculating distance traveled while accelerating.
Frictional force f is calculated as 9 N using f = μ * N and N = m * g.
Acceleration a is calculated as 3 m/s² using a = f/m.
Distance s traveled during acceleration is calculated as 6 m using v² = u² + 2as.
Object accelerates for 6 meters and then moves at constant speed for remaining 4 meters to point N.
Work done by frictional force during acceleration phase is 54 J using W = f * s.
During constant velocity phase over 4 meters, no work is done as there is no relative motion and frictional force is zero.
Total work done by frictional force from point M to N is 54 J.
Double-check reasoning about work done during constant velocity phase.
